<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='10',FILE='C:\JMS\skannan\06-1921-1\task931277\1921-1-ba-01.htm',USER='skannan',CD='Mar 16 21:15 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">To obtain the FCC&#146;s prior
consent to assign a broadcast license or transfer control of a broadcast
license, appropriate applications must be filed with the FCC.&#160; If the application involves a &#147;substantial
change&#148; in ownership or control, the application must be placed on public
notice for a period of approximately 30 days during which petitions to deny the
application may be filed by interested parties, including members of the
public.&#160; If the application does not
involve a &#147;substantial change&#148; in ownership or control, it is a &#147;pro forma&#148;
application.&#160; The &#147;pro forma&#148; application
is not subject to petitions to deny or a mandatory waiting period, but is
nevertheless subject to having informal objections filed against it.&#160; If the FCC grants an assignment or transfer
application, interested parties have approximately 30 days from public notice
of the grant to seek reconsideration or review of the grant.&#160; Generally, parties that do not file initial
petitions to deny or informal objections against the application face
difficulty in seeking reconsideration or review of the grant.&#160; The FCC normally has an additional ten days
to set aside such grant on its own motion.&#160;
When passing on an assignment or transfer application, the FCC is
prohibited from considering whether the public interest might be served by an
assignment or transfer to any party other than the assignee or transferee
specified in the application.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The FCC generally applies
its ownership limits to &#147;attributable&#148; interests held by an individual,
corporation, partnership or other association.&#160;
In the case of corporations holding, or through subsidiaries
controlling, broadcast licenses, the interests of officers, directors and those
who, directly or indirectly, have the right to vote 5% or more of the
corporation&#146;s stock (or 20% or more of such stock in the case of insurance
companies, investment companies and bank trust departments that are passive
investors) are generally attributable.&#160;
In August 1999, the FCC revised its attribution and multiple ownership
rules and adopted the equity-debt-plus rule that causes certain creditors or
investors to be attributable owners of a station.&#160; Under this rule, a major programming supplier
(any programming supplier that provides more than 15% of the station&#146;s weekly
programming hours) or same-market media entity will be an attributable owner of
a station if the supplier or same-market media entity holds debt or equity, or
both, in the station that is greater than 33% of the value of the station&#146;s
total debt plus equity.&#160; For the purposes
of this rule, equity includes all stock, whether voting or non-voting, and
equity held by insulated limited partners in partnerships.&#160; Debt includes all liabilities whether
long-term or short-term.&#160; In addition,
LMAs are attributable where a licensee owns a television station and programs more
than 15% of another television station in the same market.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Communications Act
prohibits the issuance of a broadcast license to, or the holding of a broadcast
license by, any corporation of which more than 20% of the capital stock is
owned of record or voted by non-U. S. citizens or their representatives or by a
foreign government or a representative thereof, or by any corporation organized
under the laws of a foreign country (collectively, aliens).&#160; The Communications Act also authorizes the
FCC, if the FCC determines that it would be in the public interest, to prohibit
the issuance of a broadcast license to, or the holding of a broadcast license
by, any corporation directly or indirectly controlled by any other corporation
of which more than 25% of the capital stock is owned of record or voted by
aliens.&#160; The FCC has issued interpretations
of existing law under which these restrictions in modified form apply to other
forms of business organizations, including partnerships.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As a result of these
provisions, the licenses granted to our subsidiaries by the FCC could be
revoked if, among other restrictions imposed by the FCC, more than 25% of our
stock were directly or indirectly owned or voted by aliens.&#160; Sinclair and its subsidiaries are domestic
corporations, and the members of the Smith family (who together hold approximately
almost 85% of the common voting rights of Sinclair) are all United States
citizens.&#160; Our amended and restated
Articles of Incorporation (the amended certificate) contain limitations on
alien ownership and control that are substantially similar to those contained
in the Communications Act.&#160; Pursuant to
the amended certificate, we have the right to repurchase alien-owned shares at
their fair market value to the extent necessary, in the judgment of the Board
of Directors, to comply with the alien ownership restrictions.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In June 2003, the FCC
adopted a Report and Order modifying its multiple ownership rules.&#160; The 2003 rules, among other things:</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>increase the number of stations an
entity may own nationally by increasing the national audience reach cap from
35% to 45% and leave unchanged the method of calculating an entities audience
reach.&#160; Congress subsequently passed a
bill requiring the FCC to establish a national audience reach cap of 39%.&#160; (See discussion below in <i><font style="font-style:italic;">National Ownership Rule</font></i>);</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>increase the number of stations an
entity can own or control in many local markets, subject to restrictions
including the number of stations an entity can own or control which are ranked
among the top four in their DMA;</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>repeal the newspaper-broadcast
ownership limits and replace them with general media cross-ownership limits
which, in many markets, would permit owners of daily newspapers to own one or
more television stations and/or radio stations in the same market as the
newspaper&#146;s city of publication; and</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>repeal the radio-television broadcast
ownership limits and replace them with new general media cross-ownership
limits.</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">If these rules become
law, broadcast television owners would be permitted to own more television
stations, potentially affecting our competitive position.&#160; The Third Circuit Court of Appeals has stayed
the application of the 2003 rules as a result of numerous legal challenges,
including one we filed.&#160; In July 2004,
the Court issued a decision holding, among other things, that the numerical
limits established by the FCC&#146;s 2003 local television ownership rule were
patently unreasonable and not consistent with the record evidence.&#160; The Court remanded the numerical limits for
the FCC to justify or modify and left the stay in effect pending the FCC&#146;s
action on</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">11</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='11',FILE='C:\JMS\skannan\06-1921-1\task931277\1921-1-ba-01.htm',USER='skannan',CD='Mar 16 21:15 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">remand.&#160; Several parties,
including us, have filed petitions with the Supreme Court of the United States
seeking review of the Third Circuit decision, but the Supreme Court denied the
petitions in June 2005.&#160; During the
pendency of the remand, the Third Circuit has ordered the FCC to continue to
apply the ownership rules in effect prior to the adoption of the 2003 rules.&#160; Following is a description of the FCC
ownership rules currently being applied:</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Radio/Television
Cross-Ownership Rule</font></i>.&#160;
The FCC&#146;s radio/television cross-ownership rule (the &#147;one to a market&#148;
rule) generally permits a party to own a combination of up to two television
stations and six radio stations in the same market, depending on the number of
independent media voices in the market.</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Broadcast/Daily
Newspaper Cross-Ownership Rule</font></i>.&#160; The FCC&#146;s rules prohibit the common ownership
of a radio or television broadcast station and a daily newspaper in the same
market.</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Dual
Network Rule</font></i>.&#160; The four
major television networks, FOX, ABC, CBS and NBC, are prohibited, absent a
waiver, from merging with each other.&#160; In
May 2001, the FCC amended its dual network rule to permit the four major
television networks to own, operate, maintain or control the UPN and/or the WB
television network.</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">National
Ownership Rule</font></i>.&#160; The
FCC&#146;s current national ownership rule states that no individual or entity may
have an attributable interest in television stations reaching more than 35% of
the national television viewing audience.&#160;
However, Congress passed a bill requiring the FCC to establish a
national audience reach cap of 39% and President Bush signed the bill into law
on January 23, 2004.&#160; Under this rule,
where an individual or entity has an attributable interest in more than one
television station in a market, the percentage of the national television
viewing audience encompassed within that market is only counted once.&#160; Since, historically, VHF stations (channels 2
through 13) have shared a larger portion of the market than UHF stations
(channels 14 through 69), only half of the households in the market area of any
UHF station are included when calculating an entity&#146;s national television
viewing audience (commonly referred to as the &#147;UHF discount&#148;).</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">All but seven of the
stations we own and operate, or to which we provide programming services, are
UHF.&#160; We reach approximately 22% of U. S.
television households or 12.5% taking into account the FCC&#146;s UHF discount.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Local
Television (Duopoly) Rule</font></i>.&#160;
A party may own television stations in adjoining markets, even if there
is Grade B (discussed below) overlap between the two stations&#146; analog signals
and generally may own two stations in the same market:</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>if there is no Grade B overlap
between the stations; or</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>if the market containing both the
stations will contain at least eight independently owned full-power television
stations post-merger (the &#147;eight voices test&#148;) and not more than one station is
among the top-four ranked stations in the market.</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In addition, a party may
request a waiver of the rule to acquire a second station in the market if the
station to be acquired is economically distressed or not yet constructed and
there is no party who does not own a local television station who would
purchase the station for a reasonable price.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">There are three grades of
service for traditional television broadcasts, City (strongest), Grade A and
Grade B (least strong); and the signal decreases in strength the further away
the viewer is from the broadcast antenna tower.&#160;
Generally, it is not as easy for viewers with properly installed outdoor
antennas to receive a Grade B signal, as it is to receive a Grade A or City
Grade signal.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Antitrust
Regulation</font></i>.&#160; The
Department of Justice (DOJ) and the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) have
increased their scrutiny of the television industry since the adoption of the
1996 Act and have reviewed matters related to the concentration of ownership
within markets (including LMAs) even when ownership or the LMA in question is
permitted under the laws administered by the FCC or by FCC rules and
regulations.&#160; The DOJ takes the position
that an LMA entered into in anticipation of a station&#146;s acquisition with the
proposed buyer of the station constitutes a change in beneficial ownership of
the station which, if subject to filing under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Anti Trust
Improvements Act (HSR Act), cannot be implemented until the waiting period
required by that statute has ended or been terminated.</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Expansion of our
broadcast operations on both a local and national level will continue to be
subject to the FCC&#146;s ownership rules and any changes the FCC or Congress may
adopt.&#160; At the same time, any further
relaxation of the FCC&#146;s ownership rules, which could occur if the rules adopted
in 2003 become effective, may increase the level of competition in one or more
markets in which our stations are located, more specifically to the extent that
any of our competitors may have greater resources and thereby be in a superior
position to take advantage of such changes.</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">12</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='12',FILE='C:\JMS\skannan\06-1921-1\task931277\1921-1-ba-01.htm',USER='skannan',CD='Mar 16 21:15 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div>

<h4 style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></i></b></h4>

<h4 style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Local Marketing
Agreements</font></i></b></h4>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Certain of our stations
have entered into what have commonly been referred to as local marketing
agreements or LMAs.&#160; One typical type of
LMA is a programming agreement between two separately owned television stations
serving the same market, whereby the licensee of one station programs
substantial portions of the broadcast day and sells advertising time during
such programming segments on the other licensee&#146;s station subject to the
ultimate editorial and other controls being exercised by the latter
licensee.&#160; We believe these arrangements
allow us to reduce our operating expenses and enhance profitability.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Under the FCC ownership
rules adopted in 2003, we would be allowed to continue to program most of the
stations with which we have an LMA.&#160; In
the absence of a waiver, the 2003 ownership rules would require us to terminate
or modify three of our LMAs in markets where both the station we own and the
station with which we have an LMA are ranked among the top four stations in
their particular designated market area.&#160;
The FCC&#146;s 2003 ownership rules include specific provisions permitting
waivers of this &#147;top four restriction&#148;.&#160;
Although there can be no assurances, we have studied the application of
the 2003 ownership rules to our markets and believe we are qualified for
waivers.&#160; The effective date of the 2003
ownership rules has been stayed by the U. S. Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit and the rules are on remand to the FCC.&#160;
Several parties, including us, filed petitions with the Supreme Court of
the United States seeking review of the Third Circuit decision, but the Supreme
Court denied the petitions.&#160; The FCC has
not commenced its proceeding on remand.&#160;
We cannot predict the outcome of that proceeding, which could
significantly impact our business.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">When the FCC decided to
attribute LMAs for ownership purposes in 1999, it grandfathered our LMAs that
were entered into prior to November 5, 1996, permitting the applicable stations
to continue operations pursuant to the LMAs until the conclusion of the FCC&#146;s
2004 biennial review.&#160; The FCC stated it
would conduct a case-by-case review of grandfathered LMAs and assess the
appropriateness of extending the grandfathering periods.&#160; Subsequently, the FCC invited comments as to
whether, instead of beginning the review of the grandfathered LMAs in 2004, it
should do so in 2006.&#160; The FCC has not
initiated any such review of grandfathered LMAs and we cannot predict when the
FCC will do so.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Because the effective
date of the 2003 ownership rules has been stayed and, in connection with the
adoption of those rules, the FCC concluded the old rules could not be justified
as necessary to the public interest, we have taken the position that an issue
exists regarding whether the FCC has any current legal right to enforce any
rules prohibiting the acquisition of television stations.&#160; The FCC, however, dismissed our applications
to acquire certain LMA stations.&#160; We
filed an application for review of that decision, which is still pending.&#160; In 2005, we filed a petition with the U. S.
Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit requesting that the Court direct the FCC
to take final action on our applications, but that petition was denied.&#160; We recently submitted a motion to the FCC
requesting that it take final action on our applications and that request is
pending.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On November 15, 1999, we
entered into a plan and agreement of merger to acquire through merger WBSC-TV
(formerly WFBC-TV) in Anderson, South Carolina from Cunningham Broadcasting
Corporation (Cunningham), but that transaction was denied by the FCC.&#160; In light of the change in the 2003 ownership
rules, we have filed a petition for reconsideration with the FCC and amended
our application to acquire the license of WBSC-TV.&#160; We also filed applications in November 2003
to acquire the license assets of the remaining five Cunningham stations:
WRGT-TV, Dayton, Ohio; WTAT-TV, Charleston, South Carolina; WVAH-TV,
Charleston, West Virginia; WNUV-TV, Baltimore, Maryland; and WTTE-TV, Columbus,
Ohio.&#160; The Rainbow/PUSH Coalition
(Rainbow/PUSH) filed a petition to deny these five applications and to revoke
all of our licenses.&#160; The FCC dismissed
our applications in light of the stay of the 2003 ownership rules and also
denied the Rainbow/PUSH petition. &#160;Rainbow/PUSH filed a petition for
reconsideration of that denial and we filed an application for review of the
dismissal, which may be impacted by the remand of the FCC&#146;s 2003 ownership
rules.&#160; In 2005, we filed a petition with
the U. S. Court of Appeals for the D. C. Circuit requesting that the Court
direct the FCC to take final action on our applications, but that petition was
dismissed.&#160; We recently submitted a
motion to the FCC requesting that it take final action on our
applications.&#160; Both the applications and
the associated petition to deny are still pending.&#160; We believe the Rainbow/PUSH petition is
without merit.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Satellite Home Viewer
Improvement Act (SHVIA) and the Satellite Home Viewer Extension and
Reauthorization Act (SHVERA)</font></i></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 1988, Congress enacted
the Satellite Home Viewer Act (SHVA), which enabled satellite carriers to
provide broadcast programming to those satellite subscribers who were unable to
obtain broadcast network programming over-the-air.&#160; SHVA did not permit satellite carriers to
retransmit local broadcast television signals directly to their
subscribers.&#160; The Satellite Home Viewer
Improvement Act of 1999 (SHVIA) revised SHVA to reflect changes in the
satellite and broadcasting industry.&#160;
This legislation allowed satellite carriers, until December 31, 2004, to
provide local television signals by satellite within a station market, and
effective January 1, 2002, required satellite carriers to carry all local
signals in any market where they carry any local signals.&#160; On or before July 1, 2001, SHVIA required all
television stations to elect to exercise certain &#147;must carry&#148; or &#147;retransmission
consent&#148; rights in connection with their carriage by satellite carriers.&#160; We have entered into compensation agreements
granting the two primary satellite carriers retransmission consent to carry all
our stations.&#160; In December 2004,
President Bush signed into law the Satellite Home Viewer Extension and
Reauthorization Act (SHVERA).&#160; SHVERA
extended, until December 31, 2009, the rights of broadcasters and satellite</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">13</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='13',FILE='C:\JMS\skannan\06-1921-1\task931277\1921-1-ba-01.htm',USER='skannan',CD='Mar 16 21:15 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">carriers under SHVIA to retransmit local television signals by
satellite.&#160; SHVERA also authorized
satellite delivery of distant network signals, significantly viewed signals and
local low-power television station signals into local markets under defined
circumstances.&#160; With respect to digital
signals, SHVERA established a process to allow satellite carriers to retransmit
distant network signals and significantly viewed signals and <font style="background:white;">to subscribers under certain circumstances</font>.&#160; In November 2005, the FCC completed a
rulemaking proceeding enabling the satellite carriage of &#147;significantly viewed&#148;
signals.&#160; In December 2005, the FCC
concluded a study, as required by SHVERA, regarding the applicable technical
standards for determining when a subscriber may receive a distant digital
network signal.&#160; The carriage of programming
from two network stations to a local market on the same satellite system could
result in a decline in viewership of the local network station, adversely impacting
the revenues of our affected owned and programmed stations.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h4 style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Must
Carry/Retransmission Consent</font></i></b></h4>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Pursuant to the Cable Act
of 1992, television broadcasters are required to make triennial elections to
exercise either certain &#147;must-carry&#148; or &#147;retransmission consent&#148; rights in
connection with their carriage by cable systems in each broadcaster&#146;s local
market.&#160; By electing the must-carry
rights, a broadcaster demands carriage on a specific channel on cable systems
within its DMA, in general, as defined by the Nielsen DMA Market and
Demographic Rank Report of the prior year.&#160;
These must-carry rights are not absolute and their exercise is dependent
on variables such as:</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>the number of activated channels on a
cable system;</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>the location and size of a cable
system; and</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>the amount of programming on a
broadcast station that duplicates the programming of another broadcast station
carried by the cable system.</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Therefore, under certain
circumstances, a cable system may decline to carry a given station.&#160; Alternatively, if a broadcaster chooses to
exercise retransmission consent rights, it can prohibit cable systems from
carrying its signal or grant the appropriate cable system the authority to
retransmit the broadcast signal for a fee or other consideration.&#160; In October 2005, we elected must-carry and
retransmission consent with respect to each of our stations based on our
evaluation of the respective markets and the position of our owned or
programmed station(s) within the market.&#160;
Our stations continue to be carried on all pertinent cable systems and
we do not believe that our elections have resulted in the shifting of our
stations to less desirable cable channel locations.&#160; Many of the agreements we have negotiated for
cable carriage of our analog signal are short term, subject to month-to-month
extensions.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In February 2005, the FCC
adopted an order stating that cable television systems are not required to
carry both a station&#146;s analog and digital signals during the digital transition
period.&#160; Thus, only television stations
operating solely with digital signals are entitled to mandatory carriage of
their digital signal by cable companies.&#160;
In addition, it is technically possible for a television station to
broadcast more than one channel of programming using its digital signal.&#160; The same FCC order clarified that cable
systems need only carry a broadcast station&#146;s primary video stream and not any
of the station&#146;s other programming streams in those situations where a station
chooses to transmit multiple programming streams.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Many of the viewers of
our television stations receive the signal of the stations via cable television
service.&#160; Cable television systems
generally transmit our signals pursuant to permission granted by us in retransmission
consent agreements.&#160; A material portion
of these agreements have no definite term and may be terminated either by us or
by the applicable cable television company on very short notice (usually 45 to
60 days).&#160; We are currently engaged in
negotiations with respect to these agreements with several major cable
television companies and during 2005, we reached an agreement with Comcast, our
nation&#146;s largest cable operator.&#160; There
can be no assurance that the results of these negotiations will be advantageous
to us or that we or the cable companies might not determine to terminate some
or all of these agreements.&#160; A
termination of our retransmission agreements would make it more difficult for
our viewers to watch our programming and could result in lower ratings and a
negative financial impact on us.&#160; In
addition, we generally have not provided the major cable television companies
with the right to transmit our stations&#146; digital signals.&#160; Although the lack of carriage of these
signals does not, at this time, have a material impact on our financial
statements, this could change as the number of households in the United States
with the capability of viewing digital and high definition television
increases.&#160; There can be no assurances
that we will be able to negotiate mutually acceptable retransmission agreements
in the future relating to the carriage of our digital signals.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h4 style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Syndicated
Exclusivity/Territorial Exclusivity</font></i></b></h4>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The FCC&#146;s syndicated
exclusivity rules allow local broadcast television stations to demand that
cable operators black out syndicated non-network programming carried on &#147;distant
signals&#148; (i.e. signals of broadcast stations, including so-called &#147;superstations&#148;,
which serve areas substantially removed from the cable systems&#146; local
community).&#160; The FCC&#146;s network
non-duplication rules allow local broadcast, network affiliated stations to
require that cable operators black out duplicate network</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">14</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='14',FILE='C:\JMS\skannan\06-1921-1\task931277\1921-1-ba-01.htm',USER='skannan',CD='Mar 16 21:15 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">programming carried on distant signals.&#160;
However, in a number of markets in which we own or program stations
affiliated with a network, a station that is affiliated with the same network
in a nearby market is carried on cable systems in our markets.&#160; This is not necessarily a violation of the
FCC&#146;s network non-duplication rules.&#160;
However, the carriage of two network stations on the same cable system
could result in a decline of viewership, adversely affecting the revenues of
our owned or programmed stations.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In December 2004,
President Bush signed into law the Satellite Home Viewer Extension and
Reauthorization Act (SHVERA).&#160; Among
other things, SHVERA allows satellite carriers to transmit distant signals and
the signals of &#147;significantly viewed&#148; stations under certain
circumstances.&#160; In November 2005, the FCC
completed a rulemaking proceeding enabling the satellite carriage of &#147;significantly
viewed&#148; signals.&#160; In December 2005, the
FCC concluded a study, as required by SHVERA, regarding the applicable
technical standards for determining when a subscriber may receive a distant
digital network signal.&#160; The carriage of
programming of two network stations to a local market on the same satellite
system could result in a decline in viewership of the local network station,
adversely impacting the revenues of our affected owned and programmed stations.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h4 style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Digital Television</font></i></b></h4>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The FCC has taken a
number of steps to implement digital television (DTV) broadcasting
services.&#160; The FCC has adopted an
allotment table that provides all authorized television stations with a second
channel on which to broadcast a DTV signal. The FCC has attempted to provide
DTV coverage areas that are comparable to stations&#146; existing service
areas.&#160; The FCC has ruled that television
broadcast licensees may use their digital channels for a wide variety of
services such as high-definition television, multiple standard definition
television programming, audio, data and other types of communications, subject
to the requirement that each broadcaster provide at least one free video
channel equal in quality to the current technical standard and further subject
to the requirement that broadcasters pay a fee of 5% of gross revenues from any
DTV ancillary or supplementary service for which there is a subscription fee or
for which the licensee receives a fee from a third party.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">DTV channels are
generally located in the range of channels from channel 2 through channel
51.&#160; All commercial stations were
required to have begun digital broadcasting by May 1, 2002.&#160; Under the FCC&#146;s rules, all DTV stations are
required to operate at all times in which their analog stations are
operating.&#160; In September 2004, the FCC
eliminated its requirement that a digital station simulcast a certain
percentage of the programming transmitted on its associated analog station.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As of December 31, 2004,
DTV stations were required to meet a certain signal strength standard for the
digital signal coverage in their communities of license.&#160; By July 2005, a DTV licensee affiliated with
a top four network (i.e, FOX, ABC, CBS or NBC) that is located in one of the
top 100 markets was required to meet a higher replication standard or lose
interference protection for those areas not covered by the digital signal.&#160; For a station subject to this deadline which
had not yet received a construction permit, the FCC required that such station
build a &#147;checklist&#148; facility by August 2005.&#160;
We filed requests, that are still pending, for extensions and waivers of
these deadlines for the following stations:&#160;
WUTV-DT, Buffalo, New York; WGME-DT, Portland, Maine; WLOS-DT Asheville,
North Carolina and WSMH-DT, Flint, Michigan.&#160;
For all other commercial DTV licensees, as well as non-commercial DTV
licensees, the applicable higher replication standard must be met by July
2006.&#160; There are no guarantees that our
stations will be able to meet these requirements or that our extension and
waiver requests will be granted.&#160; Loss of
interference protection for any of our stations could reduce the number of
viewers of that station and could adversely impact revenues for that station.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We operate our television
stations at different power levels pursuant to our FCC licenses, applicable
permits or special temporary authority granted by the FCC.&#160; The following table is a summary of our
operating status as of December 31, 2005:</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="85%" style="border-collapse:collapse;margin-left:.25in;width:85.0%;">

  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:2.0%;">

  </td>

  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:1.0%;">

  </td>
  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:1.0%;">
