  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="84%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:84.98%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 10.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Applications
  pending for construction permits</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:2.0%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="12%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:12.0%;">
  <p align="right" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">1</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:1.0%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="84%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:84.98%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 10.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">License pending
  but operating under special temporary authority due to equipment problems</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:2.0%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="12%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:12.0%;">
  <p align="right" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">1</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:1.0%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="84%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:84.98%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 10.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in .7pt 0in;width:2.0%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="12%" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 1.5pt;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:12.0%;">
  <p align="right" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">58</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in .7pt 0in;width:1.0%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In April 2003, the FCC
adopted a policy of graduated sanctions to be imposed upon licensees who do not
meet the FCC&#146;s DTV build-out schedule.&#160;
Under the policy, the stations could face monetary fines and possible
loss of any digital construction permits for non-compliance with the build-out
schedule.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">After completion of the
transition period, the FCC will reclaim the non-digital channels.&#160; Congress recently passed legislation
establishing a hard deadline of February 17, 2009 by which broadcasters must
cease using their analog channel.&#160; There
can be no</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">15</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='15',FILE='C:\JMS\skannan\06-1921-1\task931277\1921-1-ba-01.htm',USER='skannan',CD='Mar 16 21:15 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">assurance that the stations we own or program will be fully
transitioned to digital broadcasts by this deadline.&#160; A station&#146;s failure to meet the deadline
could result in a loss of interference protection or the applicable FCC
license, adversely impacting the revenues of our owned and programmed stations.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Implementation of digital
television has imposed substantial additional costs on television stations
because of the need to replace equipment and because some stations will need to
operate at higher utility costs.&#160; There
can be no assurance that our television stations will be able to increase
revenue to offset such costs.&#160; In
addition, the FCC has proposed imposing new public interest requirements on
television licensees in exchange for their receipt of DTV channels.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">There is considerable
uncertainty about the final form of the FCC digital regulations.&#160; Even so, we believe that these new
developments may have the following effects on us:</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Reclamation
of analog channels</font></i>.&#160;
Analog broadcasters are required to cease operation on their assigned
analog spectrum by February 17, 2009.&#160; At
that time, the FCC will reclaim this spectrum from broadcasters and make it
available to the entities who have been assigned the spectrum through FCC
auctions.&#160; The FCC envisions that the
reclaimed band will be used for a variety of broadcast-type applications
including two-way interactive services and services using Coded Orthogonal
Frequency Division Multiplexing technology.&#160;
We cannot predict how the development of this spectrum will affect our
television operations.</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Digital
must carry</font></i>.&#160; In
February 2005, the FCC adopted an order stating that cable television systems
are not required to carry both a station&#146;s analog and digital signals during
the digital transition.&#160; The same order
also clarified that a cable system must only carry a broadcast station&#146;s
primary video stream but is not required to carry any of the station&#146;s other
programming streams in those situations where a station chooses to transmit
multiple programming streams.</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Cable television systems generally transmit our
signals pursuant to permission granted by us in retransmission consent
agreements.&#160; A material portion of these
agreements for our analog signal have no definite term and may be terminated
either by us or by the applicable cable television company on very short notice
(usually 45 to 60 days).&#160; We generally
have not provided the major cable television companies with the right to
transmit our stations&#146; digital signals.&#160; We
are currently engaged in negotiations with respect to these agreements with
several major cable television companies and during 2005, we reached an
agreement with Comcast, our nation&#146;s largest cable operator.&#160; A termination of our retransmission
agreements would make it more difficult for our viewers to watch our
programming and could result in lower ratings and a negative financial impact
on us.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Multi-Channel
Digital Broadcasting</font></i>.&#160;
FCC rules allow broadcasters to transmit additional digital signals
within the spectrum allocated to each FCC license holder.&#160; We are currently broadcasting a single
digital signal for each of our television stations.&#160; In May, 2006 we will begin broadcasting a
second digital signal in Baltimore, Maryland.</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Capital
and operating costs</font></i>.&#160;
We have incurred and will continue to incur costs to replace equipment
in our stations in order to provide digital television.&#160; Some of our stations will also incur increased
utilities costs as a result of broadcasting with analog and digital signals
during the transition period.</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Children&#146;s
programming</font></i>.&#160; In 2004,
the FCC established children&#146;s educational and informational programming
obligations for digital multicast broadcasters and placed restrictions on the
increasing commercialization of children&#146;s programming on both analog and
digital broadcast and cable television systems.&#160;
In addition to imposing its limit as to the amount of commercial matter
in children&#146;s programming (10.5 minutes per hour on weekends and 12 minutes per
hour on weekdays) on all digital or video programming, free or pay, directed to
children 12 years old and younger, the FCC also mandated that digital
broadcasters air an additional half hour of &#147;core&#148; children&#146;s programming per
every increment of 1 to 28 hours of free video programming provided in addition
to the main DTV program stream.&#160; The
additional core children&#146;s programming requirement for digital broadcasters has
not yet taken effect.</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Emergency
Alert System</font></i>.&#160; In
November 2005, the FCC adopted an order requiring that digital broadcasters
comply with the FCC&#146;s present Emergency Alert System (EAS) rules.&#160; It also issued a further notice of proposed
rulemaking seeking comments on what actions the FCC should take to expedite the
development of a digitally based public alert and warning system.&#160; Any additional EAS requirements on digital
broadcasters could increase our costs.</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h4 style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Restrictions on
Broadcast Programming</font></i></b></h4>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Advertising of cigarettes
and certain other tobacco products on broadcast stations has been banned for
many years.&#160; Various states also restrict
the advertising of alcoholic beverages and, from time to time, certain members
of Congress have contemplated legislation to place restrictions on the
advertisement of such alcoholic beverages.&#160;
FCC rules also restrict the amount and type of advertising</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">16</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='16',FILE='C:\JMS\skannan\06-1921-1\task931277\1921-1-ba-01.htm',USER='skannan',CD='Mar 16 21:15 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">which can appear in a program broadcast primarily for an audience of
children 12 years old and younger.&#160; In
addition, the Federal Trade Commission issued guidelines in December 2003 and
continues to provide advice to help media outlets voluntarily screen out weight
loss product advertisements that are misleading.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Communications Act
and FCC rules also place restrictions on the broadcasting of advertisements by
legally qualified candidates for elective office.&#160; Those restrictions state that:</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>stations must provide &#147;reasonable
access&#148; for the purchase of time by legally qualified candidates for federal
office;</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>stations must provide &#147;equal
opportunities&#148; for the purchase of equivalent amounts of comparable broadcast
time by opposing candidates for the same elective office; and</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>during the 45 days preceding a
primary or primary run-off election and during the 60 days preceding a general
or special election, legally qualified candidates for elective office may be
charged no more than the station&#146;s &#147;lowest unit charge&#148; for the same class and
amount of time for the same period.</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">It is a violation of
federal law and FCC regulations to broadcast obscene or indecent
programming.&#160; FCC licensees are, in
general, responsible for the content of their broadcast programming, including
content supplied by television networks.&#160;
Accordingly, there is a risk of being fined as a result of our broadcast
programming, including network programming.&#160;
At the present time, the maximum forfeiture amount for the broadcast of
indecent or obscene material is $32,500 for each violation.&#160; In the past few years, the FCC has
intensified its scrutiny of allegedly indecent or obscene programming.&#160; The FCC&#146;s review of complaints regarding
allegedly indecent or obscene network programming broadcast on some of our FOX,
WB, NBC and ABC affiliates is delaying the grant of the applications for
license renewal of those stations.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 2005, the House of
Representatives approved a bill raising the maximum forfeiture amount to
$500,000 per violation, subject to some limitations.&#160; Additionally, the proposed law would
expressly permit the FCC to consider such violations in the context of license
renewal proceedings, proceedings for new licenses or permits and assignment or
transfer of control proceedings.&#160; The
proposed law would also require the FCC to commence a license revocation
proceeding against a licensee after three violations.&#160; This legislation is currently in the Senate
and we cannot predict the outcome.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On October 12, 2004, the
FCC issued a Notice of Apparent Liability for Forfeiture (NAL) in the amount of
$7,000 per station to virtually every FOX station, including the 15 FOX
affiliates presently licensed to us, the four FOX affiliates programmed by us
and one FOX affiliate we sold in 2005.&#160;
The NAL alleged that the stations broadcast indecent material contained
in an episode of a FOX network program that aired on April 7, 2003.&#160; We, as well as other parties including the FOX
network, filed oppositions to the NAL.&#160;
That proceeding is still pending.&#160;
Although we cannot predict the outcome of that proceeding or the effect
of any adverse outcome on the stations&#146; license renewal applications, the FOX
network has agreed to indemnify its affiliates for the full amount of this
liability.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h4 style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Programming and
Operation</font></i></b></h4>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">General</font></i>.&#160; The Communications Act requires broadcasters
to serve the &#147;public interest.&#148;&#160; The FCC has
relaxed or eliminated many of the more formalized procedures it had developed
in the past to promote the broadcast of certain types of programming responsive
to the needs of a station&#146;s community of license.&#160; FCC licensees continue to be required, however,
to present programming that is responsive to the needs and interests of their
communities and to maintain certain records demonstrating such
responsiveness.&#160; Complaints from viewers
concerning a station&#146;s programming may be considered by the FCC when it
evaluates renewal applications of a licensee, although such complaints may be
filed at any time and generally may be considered by the FCC at any time.&#160; Stations also must pay regulatory and
application fees and follow various rules promulgated under the Communications
Act that regulate, among other things, political advertising, sponsorship
identifications, obscene and indecent broadcasts and technical operations,
including limits on radio frequency radiation.</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Indecency</font></i>.&#160; It is a violation of federal law and FCC
regulations to broadcast obscene or indecent programming.&#160; FCC licensees are, in general, responsible
for the content of their broadcast programming, including that supplied by
television networks.&#160; Accordingly, there
is a risk of being fined as a result of our broadcast programming, including
network programming.&#160; Currently the
maximum forfeiture amount for the broadcast of indecent or obscene material is
$32,500 for each violation.&#160; However, in
2005, the House of Representatives approved legislation with a $500,000 cap for
indecent or obscene material.&#160; This
legislation is currently in the Senate and we cannot predict the outcome.</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Equal
Employment Opportunity</font></i>.&#160;
On November 20, 2002, the FCC adopted rules, effective March 10, 2003,
requiring licensees to create equal employment opportunity outreach programs
and maintain records and make filings with the FCC evidencing such
efforts.&#160; The FCC simultaneously released
a notice of proposed rulemaking seeking comments on whether and how to apply
these rules and policies to part-time positions, defined as less than 30 hours
per week.&#160; That rulemaking is still
pending.</p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">17</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='17',FILE='C:\JMS\skannan\06-1921-1\task931277\1921-1-ba-01.htm',USER='skannan',CD='Mar 16 21:15 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Children&#146;s
Television Programming</font></i>.&#160;
Television stations are required to broadcast a minimum of three hours
per week of &#147;core&#148; children&#146;s educational programming, which the FCC defines as
programming that:</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>has the significant purpose of
serving the educational and informational needs of children 16 years of age and
under;</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>is regularly scheduled weekly and at
least 30 minutes in duration; and</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>is aired between the hours of 7:00
a.m. and 10:00 p.m. local time.</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Furthermore, &#147;core&#148;
children&#146;s educational programs, in order to qualify as such, are required to
be identified as educational and informational programs over the air at the
time they are broadcast and are required to be identified in the children&#146;s
programming reports, which are required to be placed quarterly in stations&#146;
public inspection files and filed quarterly with the FCC.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Additionally, television
stations are required to identify and provide information concerning &#147;core&#148;
children&#146;s programming to publishers of program guides.&#160; The FCC is also applying its children&#146;s
commercial limits and policies to all digital video programming directed to
children ages 12 and under.&#160; In 2004, the
FCC concluded that a digital broadcaster must air an additional half hour of &#147;core&#148;
children&#146;s programming per every increment of 1 to 28 hours of free video
programming provided in addition to the main DTV program stream.&#160; The additional children&#146;s programming
requirement for digital broadcasters has not yet taken effect.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 2004, the FCC
initiated a notice of inquiry seeking comments on issues relating to the
presentation of violent programming on television and its impact on
children.&#160; That proceeding is still
pending.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Television
Program Content</font></i>.&#160; The
television industry has developed an FCC approved ratings system that is
designed to provide parents with information regarding the content of the
programming being aired.&#160; Furthermore,
the FCC requires certain television sets to include the so-called &#147;V-chip&#148;, a
computer chip that allows the blocking of rated programming.</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 2004, the FCC
initiated a notice of inquiry seeking comments on what actions, if any, it
should take to ensure that licensees air programming that is responsive to the
interests and needs of their communities of license.&#160; That proceeding is still pending.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Closed
Captioning</font></i>.&#160; Effective
January 1, 2006, all new nonexempt analog and digital English language programming
was required to be captioned.&#160;
Additionally, the FCC, in July 2005, initiated a rulemaking to determine
whether any revisions should be made to enhance the effectiveness of its closed
captioning rules, including monitoring compliance and the establishment of a
base forfeiture amount for noncompliance.</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h4 style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Pending Matters</font></i></b></h4>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Congress and the FCC have
under consideration and in the future may consider and adopt, new laws,
regulations and policies regarding a wide variety of matters that could affect,
directly or indirectly, the operation, ownership and profitability of our
broadcast stations, result in the loss of audience share and advertising
revenues for our broadcast stations and affect our ability to acquire additional
broadcast stations or finance such acquisitions.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Other matters that could
affect our broadcast properties include technological innovations and
developments generally affecting competition in the mass communications
industry, such as direct television broadcast satellite service, Class A
television service, the continued establishment of wireless cable systems and
low power television stations, digital television technologies, the internet
and the advent of telephone company participation in the provision of video
programming service.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h4 style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Other
Considerations</font></i></b></h4>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The preceding summary is
not a complete discussion of all provisions of the Communications Act, the 1996
Act or other congressional acts or of the regulations and policies of the
FCC.&#160; For further information, reference
should be made to the Communications Act, the 1996 Act, other congressional
acts and regulations and public notices circulated from time to time by the
FCC.&#160; There are additional regulations
and policies of the FCC and other federal agencies that govern political
broadcasts, advertising, equal employment opportunity and other matters
affecting our business and operations.</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">18</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></div>

<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h3 style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">ENVIRONMENTAL REGULATION</font></b></h3>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Prior to our ownership or
operation of our facilities, substances or waste that are or might be
considered hazardous under applicable environmental laws may have been
generated, used, stored or disposed of at certain of those facilities.&#160; In addition, environmental conditions
relating to the soil and groundwater at or under our facilities may be affected
by the proximity of nearby properties that have generated, used, stored or
disposed of hazardous substances.&#160; As a
result, it is possible that we could become subject to environmental liabilities
in the future in connection with these facilities under applicable
environmental laws and regulations.&#160;
Although we believe that we are in substantial compliance with such
environmental requirements and have not in the past been required to incur
significant costs in connection therewith, there can be no assurance that our
costs to comply with such requirements will not increase in the future.&#160; We presently believe that none of our
properties have any condition that is likely to have a material adverse effect
on our consolidated balance sheets, consolidated statements of operations or
consolidated statements of cash flows.</font></p>

<h3 style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></h3>

<h3 style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">COMPETITION</font></b></h3>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Our television stations
compete for audience share and advertising revenue with other television
stations in their respective designated market areas (DMAs), as well as with
other advertising media such as radio, newspapers, magazines, outdoor
advertising, transit advertising, telecommunications providers, internet,
yellow page directories, direct mail, satellite television, local cable
television and wireless video.&#160; Some
competitors are part of larger organizations with substantially greater
financial, technical and other resources than we have.&#160; Other factors that are material to a
television station&#146;s competitive position include signal coverage, local
program acceptance, network affiliation, audience characteristics and assigned
broadcast frequency.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Television
Competition</font></i>.&#160;
Competition in the television broadcasting industry occurs primarily in
individual DMAs.&#160; Generally, a television
broadcasting station in one DMA does not compete with stations in other
DMAs.&#160; Our television stations are
located in highly competitive DMAs.&#160; In
addition, certain of our DMAs are overlapped by over-the-air and cable carriage
of stations in adjacent DMAs, which tends to spread viewership and advertising
expenditures over a larger number of television stations.</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Broadcast television
stations compete for advertising revenues primarily with other broadcast
television stations, radio stations, cable channels, cable system operators and
satellite providers serving the same market, as well as with newspapers, the
internet, yellow page directories, direct mail, outdoor advertising operators
and transit advertisers.&#160; Television
stations compete for audience share primarily on the basis of program
popularity, which has a direct effect on advertising rates.&#160; Our affiliated stations are largely dependent
upon the performance of the networks&#146; programs in attracting viewers.&#160; Non-network time periods are programmed by
the station primarily with syndicated programs purchased for cash, cash and
barter or barter-only, as well as through self-produced news, public affairs
programs, live local sporting events and other entertainment programming.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Television advertising
rates are based upon factors which include the size of the DMA in which the
station operates, a program&#146;s popularity among the viewers that an advertiser
wishes to attract, the number of advertisers competing for the available time,
the demographic makeup of the DMA served by the station, the availability of
alternative advertising media in the DMA including radio, cable, satellite, internet,
newspapers and yellow page directories, direct mail, the aggressiveness and
knowledge of the sales forces in the DMA and development of projects, features
and programs that tie advertiser messages to programming.&#160; We believe that our sales and programming
strategies allow us to compete effectively for advertising revenues within our
DMAs.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The broadcasting industry
is continuously faced with technical changes and innovations, competing
entertainment and communications media, changes in labor conditions and
governmental restrictions or actions of federal regulatory bodies, including
the FCC, any of which could possibly have a material affect on a television
station&#146;s operations and profits.&#160; For
instance, the FCC has established Class A television service for qualifying low
power television stations.&#160; This Class A
designation provides low power television stations, which ordinarily have no
broadcast frequency rights when the low power signal conflicts with a signal
from any full power stations, some additional frequency rights.&#160; These rights may allow low power stations to
compete more effectively with full power stations.&#160; We cannot predict the effect of increased
competition from Class A television stations in markets where we have full
power television stations.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">There are sources of
video service other than conventional television stations, the most common being
cable television, which can increase competition for a broadcast television
station by bringing into its market distant broadcasting signals.&#160; These signals, not otherwise available to the
station&#146;s audience, serve as a distribution system for national satellite-delivered
programming and other non-broadcast programming originated on a cable system
and selling advertising time to local advertisers.&#160; Other principal sources of competition
include home video exhibition and Direct Broadcast Satellite (DBS) services and
Broadband Radio Service (BRS).&#160; DBS and
cable operators, in particular, are competing more aggressively than in the
past for advertising revenues. This competition could adversely affect our
stations&#146; revenues and performance in the future.&#160; In addition, SHVIA allows, on a limited
basis, satellite carriers to provide distant stations&#146; signals with the same
network affiliation as our stations to their subscribers.</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">19</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='19',FILE='C:\JMS\skannan\06-1921-1\task931277\1921-1-ba-01.htm',USER='skannan',CD='Mar 16 21:15 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Moreover, technology
advances and regulatory changes affecting programming delivery though fiber
optic telephone lines and video compression could lower entry barriers for new
video channels and encourage the development of increasingly specialized &#147;niche&#148;
programming.&#160; Telephone companies are
permitted to provide video distribution services via radio communication, on a
common carrier basis, as &#147;cable systems&#148; or as &#147;open video systems&#148;, each
pursuant to different regulatory schemes.&#160;
Additionally, in January 2004, the FCC concluded an auction for licenses
operating in the 12 GHz band that can be used to provide multi-channel video
programming distribution.&#160; Those licenses
were granted in July 2004.&#160; We are unable
to predict what other video technologies might be considered in the future or
the effect that technological and regulatory changes will have on the broadcast
television industry and on the future profitability and value of a particular
broadcast television station.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">While DTV technology is
currently available in most viewing markets, the transition of our viewers from
the current analog broadcast format to a digital format will take effect no
later than February 17, 2009.&#160; We are
currently exploring whether or not television broadcasting will be enhanced
significantly by the development and increased availability of DTV
technology.&#160; This technology has the
potential to permit us to provide viewers multiple channels of digital
television over each of our existing standard channels, to provide certain
programming in high definition television format and to deliver various forms
of data, including data on the internet, to PCs and handheld devices.&#160; These additional capabilities may provide us
with additional sources of revenue, as well as additional competition.&#160; In addition, emerging technologies that allow
viewers to digitally record and play back television programming have increased
the number of hours people spend watching television.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We also compete for
programming, which involves negotiating with national program distributors or
syndicators that sell first-run and rerun packages of programming.&#160; Our stations compete for exclusive access to
those programs against in-market broadcast station competitors for syndicated
products.&#160; Although historically cable
systems did not generally compete with local stations for programming, more
recently national cable networks have more frequently acquired programs that
would have otherwise been offered to local television stations.&#160; Public broadcasting stations generally
compete with commercial broadcasters for viewers but not for advertising
dollars.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We believe we compete
favorably against other television stations because of our management skill and
experience, our ability historically to generate revenue share greater than our
audience share, our network affiliations and our local program acceptance.&#160; In addition, we believe that we benefit from
the operation of multiple broadcast properties, affording us certain
non-quantifiable economies of scale and competitive advantages in the purchase of
programming.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h3 style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">EMPLOYEES</font></b></h3>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As of March 9, 2006, we
had approximately 2,862 employees.&#160;
Approximately 196 employees at six of our television stations are
represented by labor unions under certain collective bargaining
agreements.&#160; We have not experienced any
significant labor problems and consider our overall labor relations to be good.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h3 style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">AVAILABLE INFORMATION</font></b></h3>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Our internet address is:
www.sbgi.net. We make available, free of charge through our website, our annual
report on Form 10-K, quarterly reports on Form 10-Q, current reports on Form
8-K and amendments to those reports filed or furnished pursuant to Section
13(a) or 15(d) of the Exchange Act of 1934 as soon as reasonably practicable
after such documents are electronically submitted to the SEC.&#160; In addition, a replay of each of our
quarterly earnings conference calls is available on our website until the
subsequent quarter&#146;s earnings call.</font></p>

<h2 align="left" style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;text-align:left;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;</font></b></h2>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">20</font></p>

<div align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="center">

</font></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='20',FILE='C:\JMS\skannan\06-1921-1\task931277\1921-1-ba-01.htm',USER='skannan',CD='Mar 16 21:15 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h2 align="left" style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;text-align:left;"><a name="Item1a_RiskFactors_110457"></a><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">ITEM
1A.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; RISK FACTORS</font></b></h2>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-style:italic;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">You
should carefully consider the risks described below before investing in our
publicly traded securities.&#160; Our business
is also subject to the risks that affect many other companies such as general
economic conditions, geopolitical events, competition, technological
obsolescence and employee relations.&#160; The
risks described below, along with risks not currently known to us or that we
currently believe are immaterial, may impair our business operations and our
liquidity in an adverse way.</font></i></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Our advertising
revenue can vary substantially from period to period based on many factors
beyond our control.&#160; This volatility
affects our operating results and may reduce our ability to repay indebtedness
or reduce the market value of our securities.</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We rely on sales of
advertising time for substantially all of our revenues and, as a result, our
operating results are sensitive to the amount of advertising revenue we
generate.&#160; If we generate less revenue,
it may be more difficult for us to repay our indebtedness and the value of our
business may decline.&#160; Our ability to
sell advertising time depends on:</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>the
levels of automobile advertising, which generally represents about one fourth
of our advertising revenue;</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>the
health of the economy in the area where our television stations are located and
in the nation as a whole;</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>the
popularity of our programming;</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>changes
in the makeup of the population in the areas where our stations are located;</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>the
activities of our competitors, including increased competition from other forms
of advertising-based mediums, such as other broadcast television stations, radio
stations, satellite television providers, internet content providers, cable
system operators and telecommunication providers serving in the same markets;
and</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>other
factors that may be beyond our control.</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Our substantial
indebtedness could adversely affect our financial condition and prevent us from
fulfilling our debt obligations.</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We have a high level of
debt (totaling $1.4 billion at December 31, 2005) compared to the book value of
shareholders&#146; equity of $222.0 million on the same date.&#160; Our relatively high level of debt poses the
following risks, particularly in periods of declining revenues:</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>we
use a significant portion of our cash flow to pay principal and interest on our
outstanding debt, limiting the amount available for working capital, capital
expenditures, dividends and other general corporate purposes;</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>our
lenders may not be as willing to lend additional amounts to us for future
working capital needs, additional acquisitions or other purposes;</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>the
interest rate under the Bank Credit Agreement is a floating rate and will
increase as interest rates increase.&#160;
This will reduce the funds available to repay our obligations and for
operations and future business opportunities and will make us more vulnerable
to the consequences of our leveraged capital structure;</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>if
our cash flow were inadequate to make interest and principal payments, we might
have to refinance our indebtedness or sell one or more of our stations to
reduce debt service obligations; and</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>our
ability to finance working capital needs and general corporate purposes for the
public and private markets, as well as the associated cost of funding is
dependent, in part, by our credit ratings.&#160;
As of December 31, 2005, our credit ratings, as assigned by Moody&#146;s
Investor Services (Moody&#146;s) and Standard &amp; Poor&#146;s Ratings Services
(S&amp;P) were:</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="70%" style="border-collapse:collapse;margin-left:.9in;width:70.0%;">

  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:2.0%;">
  <p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

  <td width="12%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:12.0%;">

  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:2.0%;">
