<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">21</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='21',FILE='C:\JMS\skannan\06-1921-1\task931277\1921-1-ba-01.htm',USER='skannan',CD='Mar 16 21:15 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The credit ratings previously stated are not a
recommendation to buy, sell or hold securities and may be subject to revision
or withdrawal by the assigning rating organization.&#160; Each rating should be evaluated independently
of any other rating.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We may be more vulnerable
to adverse economic conditions than less leveraged competitors and thus, less
able to withstand competitive pressures.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Any of these events could
reduce our ability to generate cash available for investment or debt repayment
or to make improvements or respond to events that would enhance profitability.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">We
may be able to incur significantly more debt in the future, which will increase
each of the foregoing risks related to our indebtedness.</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">At December 31, 2005, we
had $167.5 million available (subject to certain borrowing conditions) for
additional borrowings under the Bank Credit Agreement, all of which was
available under our current borrowing capacity.&#160;
In addition, under the terms of our debt instruments, we may be able to
incur substantial additional indebtedness in the future, including additional
senior debt and in some cases, secured debt.&#160;
Provided we meet certain financial and other covenants, the terms of the
indentures governing our outstanding notes do not prohibit us from incurring
such additional indebtedness.&#160; If we
incur additional indebtedness, the risks described above relating to having substantial
debt could intensify.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We must purchase
television programming in advance based on expectations about future revenues.&#160; Actual revenues may be lower than our
expectations.&#160; If this happens, we could
experience losses that may make our securities less valuable.</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">One of our most significant
costs is television programming and our ability to generate revenue to cover
this cost may affect the value of our securities.&#160; If a particular program is not popular in
relation to its costs, we may not be able to sell enough advertising time to
cover the costs of the program.&#160; Since we
generally purchase programming content from others rather than produce it
ourselves, we have limited control over the costs of the programming.&#160; We usually must purchase programming several
years in advance and may have to commit to purchase more than one year&#146;s worth
of programming.&#160; Finally, we may replace
programs that are doing poorly before we have recaptured any significant
portion of the costs we incurred or before we have fully amortized the costs.&#160; Any of these factors could reduce our
revenues or otherwise cause our costs to escalate relative to revenues.&#160; These factors are exacerbated during a weak
advertising market.&#160; Additionally, our
business is subject to the popularity of the programs provided by the networks
with which we have network affiliation agreements or which provide us
programming.&#160; Excluding political
revenue, each of our affiliation groups experienced revenue increases in 2004.&#160; In 2005, some affiliates experienced slight
declines while others had increases in revenue.&#160;
Total revenue, excluding political, in 2005 increased 1.6% from 2004.&#160; We cannot predict the success of our
affiliates in the future.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Promises we have
made to our lenders limit our ability to take actions that could increase the value
of our securities or may require us to take actions that decrease the value of
our securities.</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Our existing financing agreements prevent us from
taking certain actions and require us to meet certain tests.&#160; These restrictions and tests may require us
to conduct our business in ways that make it more difficult for us to repay our
indebtedness or decrease the value of our business.&#160; These restrictions and tests include the
following:</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>restrictions
on additional debt;</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>restrictions
on our ability to pledge our assets as security for our indebtedness;</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>restrictions
on payment of dividends, the repurchase of stock and other payments relating to
capital stock;</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>restrictions
on some sales of assets and the use of proceeds from asset sales;</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>restrictions
on mergers and other acquisitions, satisfaction of conditions for acquisitions
and a limit on the total amount of acquisitions without the consent of bank
lenders;</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>restrictions
on the type of business we and our subsidiaries may be in;</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>restrictions
on the type and amounts of investments we and our subsidiaries may make; and</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>financial
ratio and condition tests including the ratio of earnings before interest, tax,
depreciation and amortization, as adjusted (adjusted EBITDA) to total interest
expense, the ratio of adjusted EBITDA to certain of our fixed expenses and the
ratio of indebtedness to adjusted EBITDA.&#160;
</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">22</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='22',FILE='C:\JMS\skannan\06-1921-1\task931277\1921-1-ba-01.htm',USER='skannan',CD='Mar 16 21:15 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Future financing arrangements may contain additional
restrictions and tests.&#160; All of these
restrictive covenants may limit our ability to pursue our business strategies,
prevent us from taking action that could increase the value of our securities
or may require actions that decrease the value of our securities.&#160; In addition, we may fail to meet the tests
and thereby default on one or more of our obligations (particularly if the
economy were to soften and thereby reduces our advertising revenues).&#160; If we default on our obligations, creditors
could require immediate payment of the obligations or foreclose on
collateral.&#160; If this happens, we could be
forced to sell assets or take other actions that could significantly reduce the
value of our securities and we may not have sufficient assets or funds to pay
our debt obligations.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">We
may lose a large amount of programming if a network terminates its affiliation
with us, which could increase our costs and/or reduce revenue.</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h5 style="color:windowtext;font-weight:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;text-decoration:underline;text-indent:.5in;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Network
Affiliation Agreements</font></u></h5>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Of the 58 television
stations that we own and operate, or to which we provide programming services
or sales services, 56 currently operate as affiliates of FOX (19 stations), WB
(18 stations), ABC (10 stations), UPN (6 stations), CBS (2 stations) and NBC (1
station).&#160;&#160; The remaining two stations
are independent.&#160; The networks produce
and distribute programming in exchange for each station&#146;s commitment to air the
programming at specified times and for commercial announcement time during
programming.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On June 30, 2005, the
affiliation agreements for our FOX affiliates expired.&#160; On August 22, 2005, we entered into an
agreement that caused these expired agreements to continue in full force and
effect until terminated by either party.&#160;
We are currently in negotiations to renew the FOX affiliation agreements
on a long-term basis.&#160; At this time, we
cannot predict the final outcome of these negotiations and any impact they may
have on our consolidated balance sheets, consolidated statements of operations
or consolidated statements of cash flows.&#160;
As of December 31, 2005, the aggregate net book value of these
affiliation agreements was $37.3 million.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On October 24, 2005, NBC
informed us that they intend to terminate our affiliation with WTWC-TV in
Tallahassee, Florida.&#160; This notice is
contractually required to avoid automatic renewal of the existing agreement
which expires January 1, 2007.&#160; NBC has
stated it is willing to continue its affiliation with WTWC if revised terms and
conditions can be agreed upon.&#160; As of
December 31, 2005, the net book value of this affiliation agreement was $2.3
million.&#160; We continue to negotiate with
NBC regarding our affiliation agreement and, at this time, we cannot predict
the final outcome of these negotiations and any impact they may have on our
consolidated balance sheets, consolidated statements of operations or
consolidated statements of cash flows.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On January 24, 2006, CBS
Corporation (CBS) and Warner Bros. Entertainment (Warner Bros.) announced their
intent to merge the operations of their respective networks, UPN and The WB, into
a broadcasting network to be called The CW Television Network.&#160; On March 2, 2006, we announced that we agreed
with Twentieth Television, Inc. to air MyNetworkTV primetime programming on 17
of our stations.&#160; At this time, we cannot
predict which of our stations will be affiliated with The CW, nor can we
predict whether CBS or Warner Bros. will honor certain agreements, including
affiliation agreements, that were made with us in the past.&#160; The aggregate net book value of our UPN and
WB affiliation agreements was $9.0 million as of December 31, 2005.&#160; Refer to our <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Markets and
Stations </font></i>table on page 5 and <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Note 18.</font></i>  <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Subsequent Events,</font></i> in the Notes to our Consolidated
Financial Statements for additional information regarding these announcements.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 31.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The non-renewal or termination of any of our other
network affiliation agreements would prevent us from being able to carry
programming of the relevant network.&#160;
This loss of programming would require us to obtain replacement
programming, which may involve higher costs and which may not be as attractive
to our target audiences, resulting in reduced revenues.&#160; Upon the termination of any of the above
affiliation agreements, we would be required to establish a new affiliation
agreement with another network or operate as an independent station.&#160; At such time, the remaining value of the
network affiliation asset could become impaired and we would be required to
write down the value of the asset.&#160; At
this time, we cannot predict the final outcome of future negotiations and what
impact, if any, they may have on our consolidated balance sheets, consolidated statements
of operations or consolidated statements of cash flows.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 31.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">A change in a critical accounting
estimate that affects the accounting treatment of goodwill and FCC licenses
could cause material future losses due to asset impairment.</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In June 2001, the Financial Accounting Standards Board
(FASB) approved SFAS No. 142, <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Goodwill and Other
Intangible Assets</font></i> (SFAS 142).&#160;
SFAS 142 requires companies to cease amortizing goodwill and certain
other intangible assets including FCC licenses.&#160;
SFAS 142 also establishes a method of testing goodwill and FCC licenses
for impairment on an annual basis, or on an interim basis if an event occurs
that would reduce the fair value of a reporting unit below its carrying value.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We test our goodwill and FCC licenses for
impairment.&#160; To perform this test, we
estimate the fair values of our station assets and liabilities using a
combination of observed prices paid for similar assets and liabilities, discounted
cash flow models and </font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">23</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='23',FILE='C:\JMS\skannan\06-1921-1\task931277\1921-1-ba-01.htm',USER='skannan',CD='Mar 16 21:15 2006' -->



<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

<div>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">appraisals.&#160; We
make certain critical estimates about the future revenue growth rates within
each of our markets as well as the discount rates that would be used by market
participants in an arms-length transaction.&#160;
If these growth rates decline or if the discount rate increases, our
goodwill and/or FCC licenses could be impaired.&#160;
An impairment of some or all of the value of these assets could result
in a material effect on the consolidated statements of operations.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Key officers and
directors have financial interests that are different and sometimes opposite
our own and we may engage in transactions with these officers and directors
that may benefit them to the detriment of other securityholders.</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Some of our officers, directors and majority
shareholders own stock or partnership interests in businesses that engage in
television broadcasting, do business with us or otherwise do business that
conflicts with our interests.&#160; They may
transact some business with us upon approval by the independent members of our
Board of Directors even if there is a conflict of interest or they may engage
in business competitive to our business and those transactions may benefit the
officers, directors or majority shareholders to the detriment of our
securityholders.&#160; David D. Smith,
Frederick G. Smith, and J. Duncan Smith are each an officer and director of
Sinclair and Robert E. Smith is a director of Sinclair.&#160; Together, the Smiths hold shares of our
common stock that control the outcome of most matters submitted to a vote of
shareholders.&#160; The Smiths own a controlling
interest in a television station which we program pursuant to an LMA.&#160; The Smiths also own businesses that lease
real property and tower space to us and engage in other transactions with
us.&#160; David D. Smith, Frederick G. Smith,
J. Duncan Smith, Robert E. Smith and David B. Amy, our Executive Vice President
and Chief Financial Officer, together own less than 2.5% of Allegiance Capital
Limited Partnership, a limited partnership in which we hold a 87.5%
interest.&#160; Also, David D. Smith,
Frederick G. Smith, J. Duncan Smith and Robert E. Smith together own less than
1.0% of the stock of G1440, a company of which we own approximately 94.0% and David
D. Smith owns approximately 0.1% of Acrodyne Communications, Inc., a company of
which we own approximately 82.3%.&#160; We can
give no assurance that these transactions or any transactions that we may enter
into in the future with our officers, directors or majority shareholders, have
been, or will be, negotiated on terms as favorable to us as we would obtain
from unrelated parties.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Maryland law and our financing agreements limit the
extent to which our officers, directors and majority shareholders may transact
business with us and pursue business opportunities that we might pursue.&#160; These limitations do not, however, prohibit
all such transactions.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">For additional information related to our investments,
see <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Note 11. Related Party Transactions,</font></i>
in the Notes to our Consolidated Financial Statements.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Smiths
exercise control over most matters submitted to a shareholder vote and may have
interests that differ from yours.&#160; They
may, therefore, take actions that are not in the interests of other
securityholders.</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">David D. Smith, Frederick G. Smith, J. Duncan Smith
and Robert E. Smith hold shares representing approximately 85% of the common
stock voting rights and, therefore, control the outcome of most matters
submitted to a vote of shareholders, including, but not limited to, electing
directors, adopting amendments to our certificate of incorporation and
approving corporate transactions.&#160; The
Smiths hold substantially all of the Class B Common Stock, which have ten votes
per share.&#160; Our Class A Common Stock has
only one vote per share.&#160; In addition,
the Smiths hold half our board of directors&#146; seats and, therefore, have the
power to exert significant influence over our corporate management and
policies.&#160; The Smiths have entered into a
stockholders&#146; agreement pursuant to which they have agreed to vote for each
other as candidates for election to the board of directors until June 13, 2015.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Circumstances may occur in which the interests of the
Smiths, as the controlling equity holders, could be in conflict with the
interests of other securityholders and the Smiths would have the ability to
cause us to take actions in their interest.&#160;
In addition, the Smiths could pursue acquisitions, divestitures or other
transactions that, in their judgment could enhance their equity investment,
even though such transactions might involve risks to our other
securityholders.&#160; (See <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Item 12. Security Ownership of Certain Beneficial
Owners</font></i>  <i><font style="font-style:italic;">and Management and Related Stockholder Matters</font></i>
and <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Item 13. Certain Relationships and
Related Transactions</font></i>.)</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Certain features
of our capital structure that discourage others from attempting to acquire our
company may prevent our securityholders from receiving a premium on their
securities or result in a lower price for our securities.</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The control the Smiths have over shareholder votes may
discourage other parties from trying to acquire us.&#160; Anyone trying to acquire us would likely
offer to pay more for shares of Class A Common Stock than the amount those
shares were trading for in the open market at the time of the offer.&#160; If the voting rights of the Smiths discourage
such takeover attempts, shareholders may be denied the opportunity to receive
such a premium.&#160; The general level of
prices for Class A Common Stock might also be lower than it would otherwise be
if these deterrents to takeovers did not exist.</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;">24</font></b></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></b></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='24',FILE='C:\JMS\eudelhofen\06-1921-1\task933317\1921-1-ba-03.htm',USER='eudelho',CD='Mar 16 16:04 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Federal
regulation of the broadcasting industry limits our operating flexibility, which
may affect our ability to generate revenue or reduce our costs.</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The FCC regulates our business, just as it does all
other companies in the broadcasting industry.&#160;
We must ask the FCC&#146;s approval whenever we need a new license, seek to
renew, assign or modify a license, purchase a new station, sell an existing
station or transfer the control of one of our subsidiaries that holds a license.&#160; Our FCC licenses and those of the stations we
program pursuant to LMAs are critical to our operations; we cannot operate
without them.&#160; We cannot be certain that
the FCC will renew these licenses in the future or approve new
acquisitions.&#160; If licenses are not
renewed or acquisitions approved, we may lose revenue that we otherwise could
have earned.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In addition, Congress and the FCC may, in the future,
adopt new laws, regulations and policies regarding a wide variety of matters
(including technological changes) that could, directly or indirectly,
materially and adversely affect the operation and ownership of our broadcast
properties.&#160; (See <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Item 1. Business.</font></i>)</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">It is a violation of federal law and FCC regulations
to broadcast obscene or indecent programming.&#160;
FCC licensees are, in general, responsible for the content of their
broadcast programming, including content supplied by television networks.&#160; Accordingly, there is a risk of being fined
as a result of our broadcast programming, including network programming.&#160; The maximum forfeiture amount for the
broadcast of indecent or obscene material is $32,500 for each violation.&#160; In the past few years, the FCC has
intensified its scrutiny of allegedly indecent and obscene programming.&#160; The FCC&#146;s review of complaints regarding
allegedly indecent or obscene network programming broadcast on some of our FOX
and WB affiliates may be delaying the grant of the applications for license
renewal of those stations.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 2005, the House of Representatives approved a bill
raising the maximum forfeiture amount to $500,000 per violation, subject to
some limitations.&#160; Additionally, the
proposed law would expressly permit the FCC to consider such violations in the
context of license renewal proceedings, proceedings for new licenses or permits
and assignment or transfer of control proceedings.&#160; The proposed law would also require the FCC
to commence a license revocation proceeding against a licensee after three
violations.&#160; This legislation is
currently in the Senate and we cannot predict the outcome.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On October 12, 2004, the FCC issued a Notice of
Apparent Liability for Forfeiture (NAL) in the amount of $7,000 per station to
virtually every FOX station, including the 15 FOX affiliates presently licensed
to us, the four FOX affiliates programmed by us and one FOX affiliate we sold
in 2005.&#160; The NAL alleged that the
stations broadcast indecent material contained in an episode of a FOX network
program that aired on April 7, 2003.&#160; We,
as well as other parties including the FOX network, filed oppositions to the
NAL.&#160; That proceeding is still
pending.&#160; Although we cannot predict the
outcome of that proceeding or the effect of any adverse outcome on the stations
license renewal applications, the FOX network has agreed to indemnify its affiliates
for the full amount of this liability.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">The
FCC&#146;s multiple ownership rules limit our ability to operate multiple television
stations in some markets and may result in a reduction in our revenue or
prevent us from reducing costs.&#160; Changes
in these rules may threaten our existing strategic approach to certain
television markets.</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Changes in Rules
on Television Ownership</font></u></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Congress passed a
bill requiring the FCC to establish a national audience reach cap of 39% and
President Bush signed the bill into law on January 23, 2004.&#160; This law permits broadcast television owners
to own more television stations nationally, potentially affecting our
competitive position.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In June 2003, the
FCC adopted new multiple ownership rules.&#160;
In July 2004, the Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit issued a
decision which upheld a portion of such rules and remanded the matter to the
FCC for further justification of the rules.&#160;
The court also issued a stay of the 2003 rules pending the remand.&#160; Several parties, including us, filed
petitions with the Supreme Court of the United States seeking review of the
Third Circuit decision, but the Supreme Court denied the petitions in June 2005.&#160; The FCC has not commenced its proceeding on
remand. &#160;We cannot predict the outcome of
that proceeding, which could significantly impact our business.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Changes in Rules
on Local Marketing Agreements</font></u></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Certain of our
stations have entered into what have commonly been referred to as local
marketing agreements or LMAs.&#160; One
typical type of LMA is a programming agreement between two separately owned
television stations serving the same market, whereby the licensee of one
station programs substantial portions of the broadcast day and sells
advertising time during such programming segments on the other licensee&#146;s
station subject to the ultimate editorial and other controls being exercised by
the latter licensee.&#160; We believe these
arrangements allow us to reduce our operating expenses and enhance
profitability.</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">25</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='25',FILE='C:\JMS\eudelhofen\06-1921-1\task933317\1921-1-ba-03.htm',USER='eudelho',CD='Mar 16 16:04 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Under the FCC
ownership rules adopted in 2003, we would be allowed to continue to program
most of the stations with which we have an LMA.&#160;
In the absence of a waiver, the 2003 ownership rules would require us to
terminate or modify three of our LMAs in markets where both the station we own
and the station with which we have an LMA are ranked among the top four
stations in their particular designated market area.&#160; The FCC&#146;s 2003 ownership rules include
specific provisions permitting waivers of this &#147;top four restriction&#148;.&#160; Although there can be no assurances, we have
studied the application of the 2003 ownership rules to our markets and believe
we are qualified for waivers.&#160; The
effective date of the 2003 ownership rules has been stayed by the U. S. Court of
Appeals for the Third Circuit and the rules are on remand to the FCC.&#160; Several parties, including us, filed
petitions with the Supreme Court of the United States seeking review of the
Third Circuit decision, but the Supreme Court denied the petitions in June 2005.&#160; The FCC has not commenced its proceeding on
remand.&#160; We cannot predict the outcome of
that proceeding, which could significantly impact our business.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">When the FCC
decided to attribute LMAs for ownership purposes in 1999, it grandfathered our LMAs
that were entered into prior to November 5, 1996, permitting the applicable
stations to continue operations pursuant to the LMAs until the conclusion of
the FCC&#146;s 2004 biennial review.&#160; The FCC
stated it would conduct a case-by-case review of grandfathered LMAs and assess
the appropriateness of extending the grandfathering periods.&#160; Subsequently, the FCC invited comments as to
whether, instead of beginning the review of the grandfathered LMAs in 2004, it
should do so in 2006.&#160; The FCC has not
initiated any such review of grandfathered LMAs and we cannot predict when the
FCC will do so.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Because the
effective date of the 2003 ownership rules has been stayed and, in connection
with the adoption of those rules, the FCC concluded the old rules could not be justified
as necessary to the public interest, we have taken the position that an issue
exists regarding whether the FCC has any current legal right to enforce any
rules prohibiting the acquisition of television stations.&#160; The FCC, however, dismissed our applications
to acquire certain LMA stations.&#160; We
filed an application for review of that decision, which is still pending.&#160; In 2005, we filed a petition with the U. S.
Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit requesting that the Court direct the FCC
to take final action on our applications, but that petition was denied.&#160; We recently submitted a motion to the FCC
requesting that it take final action on our applications and that request is
pending.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On November 15, 1999, we
entered into a plan and agreement of merger to acquire through merger WBSC-TV
(formerly WFBC-TV) in Anderson, South Carolina from Cunningham Broadcasting
Corporation (Cunningham), but that transaction was denied by the FCC.&#160; In light of the change in the 2003 ownership
rules, we have filed a petition for reconsideration with the FCC and amended
our application to acquire the license of WBSC-TV.&#160; We also filed applications in November 2003
to acquire the license assets of the remaining five Cunningham stations:
WRGT-TV, Dayton, Ohio; WTAT-TV, Charleston, South Carolina; WVAH-TV,
Charleston, West Virginia; WNUV-TV, Baltimore, Maryland; and WTTE-TV, Columbus,
Ohio.&#160; The Rainbow/PUSH Coalition
(Rainbow/PUSH) filed a petition to deny these five applications and to revoke
all of our licenses.&#160; The FCC dismissed
our applications in light of the stay of the 2003 rules and also denied the
Rainbow/PUSH petition.&#160; Rainbow/PUSH
filed a petition for reconsideration of that denial and we filed an application
for review of the dismissal, which may be impacted by the remand of the FCC&#146;s
2003 ownership rules.&#160; In 2005, we filed
a petition with the U. S. Court of Appeals for the D. C. Circuit requesting
that the Court direct the FCC to take final action on our applications, but
that petition was dismissed.&#160; We recently
submitted a motion to the FCC requesting that it take final action on our
applications.&#160; Both the applications and
the associated petition to deny are still pending.&#160; We believe the Rainbow/PUSH petition is
without merit.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">If we are required
to terminate or modify our LMAs, our business could be affected in the
following ways:</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Losses
on investments</font></i>.&#160; As
part of our LMA arrangements, we own the non-license assets used by the
stations with which we have LMAs.&#160; If
certain of these LMA arrangements are no longer permitted, we would be forced
to sell these assets, restructure our agreements or find another use for
them.&#160; If this happens, the market for
such assets may not be as good as when we purchased them and, therefore, we
cannot be certain that we will recoup our original investments.</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Termination
penalties</font></i>.&#160; If the FCC
requires us to modify or terminate existing LMAs before the terms of the LMAs
expire, or under certain circumstances, we elect not to extend the terms of the
LMAs, we may be forced to pay termination penalties under the terms of some of
our LMAs.&#160; Any such termination penalties
could be material.</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Use of outsourcing
agreements</font></u></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In addition to our
LMAs, we have entered into four (and may seek opportunities for additional)
outsourcing agreements in which our stations provide or are provided various
non-programming related services such as sales, operational and managerial
services to or by other stations.&#160;
Pursuant to these agreements, our station in Nashville, Tennessee
currently provides services to another station in the market and other parties
provide services to our stations in Peoria/Bloomington, Illinois, Cedar Rapids,
Iowa and Rochester, New York.&#160; We believe
this structure allows stations to achieve operational efficiencies and economies
of scale, which should otherwise improve broadcast cash flow and </font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">26</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='26',FILE='C:\JMS\eudelhofen\06-1921-1\task933317\1921-1-ba-03.htm',USER='eudelho',CD='Mar 16 16:04 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">competitive
positions.&#160; While television joint sales
agreements (JSAs) are not currently attributable, on August 2, 2004, the FCC released
a notice of proposed rulemaking seeking comments on its tentative conclusion
that television joint sales agreements should be attributable.&#160; We cannot predict the outcome of this
proceeding, nor can we predict how any changes, together with possible changes
to the ownership rules, would apply to our existing outsourcing agreements.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Failure of
owner/licensee to exercise control</font></u></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The FCC requires
the owner/licensee of a station to maintain independent control over the
programming and operations of the station.&#160;
As a result, the owners/licensees of those stations with which we have
LMAs or outsourcing agreements can exert their control in ways that may be counter
to our interests, including the right to preempt or terminate programming in
certain instances.&#160; The preemption and
termination rights cause some uncertainty as to whether we will be able to air
all of the programming that we have purchased and therefore, uncertainty about
the advertising revenue that we will receive from such programming.&#160; In addition, if the FCC determines that the
owner/licensee is not exercising sufficient control, it may penalize the owner
licensee by a fine, revocation of the license for the station or a denial of
the renewal of that license.&#160; Any one of
these scenarios might result in a reduction of our cash flow and an increase in
our operating costs or margins, especially the revocation of or denial of
renewal of a license.&#160; In addition,
penalties might also affect our qualifications to hold FCC licenses and thus
put those licenses at risk.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Competition from
other broadcasters or other content providers and changes in technology may
cause a reduction in our advertising revenues and/or an increase in our
operating costs.</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The television industry
is highly competitive and this competition can draw viewers and advertisers
from our stations, which reduces our revenue or requires us to pay more for
programming, which increases our costs.&#160;
We face intense competition from the following:</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">New Technology and
the subdivision of markets</font></u></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Cable providers,
direct broadcast satellite companies and telecommunication companies are
developing new technology that allows them to transmit more channels on their
existing equipment to highly targeted audiences, reducing the cost of creating
channels and potentially leading to the division of the television industry
into ever more specialized niche markets.&#160;
Competitors who target programming to such sharply defined markets may
gain an advantage over us for television advertising revenues.&#160; Lowering the cost of creating channels may
also encourage new competitors to enter our markets and compete with us for
advertising revenue.&#160; In addition,
emerging technologies that will allow viewers to digitally record, store and
play back television programming may decrease viewership of commercials and, as
a result, lower our advertising revenues.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h6 style="color:windowtext;font-weight:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;text-decoration:underline;text-indent:.5in;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Types of competitors</font></u></h6>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We also face
competition from rivals that may have greater resources than we have.&#160; These include:</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>other
local free over-the-air broadcast television and radio stations;</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>telecommunication companies;</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>cable
and satellite system operators;</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 76.5pt;text-indent:-22.5pt;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>print media providers such as
newspapers and periodicals;</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>internet providers; and</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt 1.0in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="3" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:12.0pt;">&#149;</font>&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; competition from other emerging
technologies.</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h6 style="color:windowtext;font-weight:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;text-decoration:underline;text-indent:.5in;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Deregulation</font></u></h6>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Telecommunications
Act of 1996 and subsequent actions by the FCC have removed some limits on
station ownership, allowing telephone, cable and some other companies to
provide video services in competition with us.&#160;
In addition, the FCC has reallocated a portion of the spectrum for new
services including fixed and mobile wireless services and digital broadcast
services.&#160; As a result of these changes,
new companies are able to enter our markets and compete with us.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">27</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='27',FILE='C:\JMS\eudelhofen\06-1921-1\task933317\1921-1-ba-03.htm',USER='eudelho',CD='Mar 16 16:04 2006' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The commencement
of the Iraq War resulted in a decline in advertising revenues and negatively
impacted our operating results.&#160; Future
conflicts may have a similar effect.</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The commencement of the war in Iraq resulted in a
reduction of advertising revenues as a result of uninterrupted news coverage
and general economic uncertainty.&#160; During
the first quarter of 2003, we experienced $2.2 million in advertiser
cancellations and preemptions, which resulted in lower earnings than we would
have experienced without this disruption. If the United States becomes engaged
in similar conflicts in the future, they may have a similar adverse effect on
our results of operations.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Unrelated third parties may claim
that we infringe on their rights based on the nature and content of information
posted on websites maintained by us.</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We host internet services that enable individuals and
businesses to exchange information, generate content, advertise products and
services, conduct business and engage in various online activities.&#160; The law relating to the liability of
providers of these online services for activities of their users is currently
unsettled both within the United States and internationally.&#160; Claims may be brought against us for
defamation, negligence, copyright or trademark infringement, unlawful activity,
tort, including personal injury, fraud, or other theories based on the nature
and content of information that we provide links to or that may be posted
online or generated by our users.&#160; Our
defense of such actions could be costly and involve significant time and
attention of our management and other resources.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">We
have lost money in two of the last five years, and may continue to incur losses
in the future, which may impair our ability to pay our debt obligations</font></b>.</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We reported earnings in 2005, 2004 and 2003, but we
have incurred net losses in two of the last five years.&#160; Our losses are due to a variety of cash and
non-cash expenses which may or may not recur.&#160;
Our net losses may therefore continue indefinitely and as a result, we
may not have sufficient funds to operate our business.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h2 align="left" style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;text-align:left;"><a name="Item1b_UnresolvedStaffComments_110520"></a><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">ITEM 1B.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; UNRESOLVED
STAFF COMMENTS</font></b></h2>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">None.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h2 align="left" style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;text-align:left;"><a name="Item2_Properties_110535"></a><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">ITEM
2.&#160; PROPERTIES</font></b></h2>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Generally, each of our
stations has facilities consisting of offices, studios and tower sites.&#160; Transmitter and tower sites are located to
provide maximum signal coverage of our stations&#146; markets.&#160; The following is a summary of our principal
owned and leased real properties.&#160; We
believe that no one property represents a material amount of the total
properties owned or leased.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h2 align="left" style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;text-align:left;"><a name="Item3_LegalProceedings_110552"></a><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">ITEM 3.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; LEGAL
PROCEEDINGS</font></b></h2>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We are a party to
lawsuits and claims from time to time in the ordinary course of business.&#160; Actions currently pending are in various
preliminary stages and no judgments or decisions have been rendered by hearing
boards or courts in connection with such actions.&#160; After reviewing developments to date with
legal counsel, our management is of the opinion that the outcome of our pending
and threatened matters will not have a material adverse effect on our consolidated
balance sheets, consolidated statements of operations or consolidated statements
of cash flows.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Subsequent to our airing
a news program in 2004, <i><font style="font-style:italic;">POW Story: Politics,
Pressure and the Media</font></i>, certain parties filed formal complaints
against us and certain of our employees and directors with the Federal Election
Commission (FEC).&#160; On June 13, 2005, the
FEC concluded unanimously that neither we nor our employees or directors
violated any campaign finance laws and that our broadcast activities were
protected by &#147;press exemption.&#148;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h2 align="left" style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;text-align:left;"><a name="Item4_SubmissionOfMattersToAVoteO_110556"></a><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">ITEM 4.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; SUBMISSION
OF MATTERS TO A VOTE OF SECURITY HOLDERS</font></b></h2>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">No matters were submitted
to a vote of our shareholders during the fourth quarter of 2005.</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">28</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left"></div>

<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><a name="PartIi_111022"></a><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">PART II</font></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .8in;text-indent:-.8in;"><a name="Item5_MarketForRegistrantsCommonE_111024"></a><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">ITEM
5.</font></b><font size="1" style="font-size:8.5pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>MARKET FOR REGISTRANT&#146;S
COMMON EQUITY, RELATED STOCKHOLDER MATTERS AND ISSUER PURCHASES OF EQUITY
SECURITIES</p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Our Class A Common Stock
is listed for trading on the NASDAQ stock market under the symbol SBGI.&#160; Our Class B Common Stock is not traded on a
market.&#160; The following tables set forth
for the periods indicated the high and low closing sales prices on the NASDAQ
stock market.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="70%" style="border-collapse:collapse;margin-left:.75in;width:70.0%;">
 <tr>
  <td width="53%" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:53.96%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;font-weight:bold;">2005</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="3%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:3.18%;">
  <p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="19%" colspan="2" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:19.06%;">

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As of March 9, 2006,
there were approximately 82 shareholders of record of our common stock.&#160; This number does not include beneficial
owners holding shares through nominee names.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We did not repurchase any
Class A Common Stock during 2005.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Dividend Policy</font></i></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Future dividends on our
common shares, if any, will be at the discretion of our Board of Directors and
will depend on several factors including our results of operations, cash
requirements and surplus, financial condition, covenant restrictions and other
factors that the Board of Directors may deem relevant.&#160; Our current dividend of $0.10 per share per
quarter is not in excess of any applicable restrictions or conditions contained
within the indentures of our various senior subordinated notes.&#160; We expect to continue to pay this dividend in
the foreseeable future.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In May 2004, we declared
a quarterly cash dividend on our Class A and Class B Common Stock for the first
time in our company&#146;s history.&#160; For the
quarters ended June 30, 2004, September 30, 2004 and December 31, 2004, we paid
dividends of $0.025 per share of our common stock.&#160; During 2005, the Board of Directors voted to
increase that dividend on three occasions.&#160;
The dividends declared were as follows:</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Convertible Bond Repurchases</font></i></b></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">During the fourth quarter,
we repurchased, in the open market, $5.0 million of our 6.0% Convertible
Debentures, due 2012 at face value.</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h2 align="left" style="color:windowtext;font-weight:bold;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;text-align:left;"><a name="Item6_SelectedFinancialData_111034"></a><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">ITEM 6.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; SELECTED
FINANCIAL DATA</font></b></h2>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The selected consolidated
financial data for the years ended December 31, 2005, 2004, 2003, 2002 and 2001
have been derived from our audited consolidated financial statements.&#160; The consolidated financial statements for the
years ended December 31, 2005, 2004 and 2003 are included elsewhere in this
report.</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">30</font></p>

<div style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left"></div>

</div>

<div>

<p align="center" style="color:windowtext;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

should be read in conjunction with <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Management&#146;s
Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations</font></i>
and the consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this report.</font></p>

OF OPERTIONS DATA</font></b></p>
